Luckily you can move if the education system sucks. You know, one really interesting point that came across to me in this comment is just how "late" history goes. In college (early 90's), my second-term U.S. history prof noted that it would be really difficult for him to maintain "the historian's objectivity" near the end of the course, because he lived through the 50's and 60's, and even we students were around during the 70's and 80's. The times being discussed were too recent to know what was truly important or not, and what's merely colored one way or the other by the subjectivity of memory. He warned us to take everything he said with a grain of salt -- and even to take a few things we thought we knew with a grain of salt, as well. Of course, my high school history class ended at World War II.... Gosh, what a bad history teacher I had then. But in any event, here's what I'm curious about: What are the main items of post-Vietnam history that should be discussed in a high school history book? What people and events should be discussed? What long trends or broad patterns need attention? And what people and events whom we might find important should be subsumed under those larger phenomena, rather than dealt with in their own right? Like I said, just curious.
